reviewText:
A gritty double-edged storytelling, worthy of the Game of Thrones name.

Do not be deceived by the gameplay and graphics, ice and darkness! they are horrible and dated. But if you can go through the first 10 hours of the game, you will want to finish the game. because YES this is a fantastic narrative and you will reap your rewards in the end.

You will need a dose of patience, this game filters off casual players, it has terrible gameplay mechanics and expensive high end weapons, the levelling does not help either. The lighting in the game is too dark for my taste and and if you use a controller like me the minimap disappear!! The interface can be frustrating with its dial-select options. But you will forget about all that as you progress in the game. It has some moments, dark humour, tragedies and satisfactory voice-acted dialogues (I must warn you, there are a lots of cutscenes).

The game bears similarities to the moral choices pioneered by Starwars KOTOR as well as the pauseable combats. I enjoyed the story immensely, you will appreciate this more if you watched at least the first season of the HBO TV series. my final verdict, give this game a chance, you might like it as I did.

reviewText:
I'm really struggling with this game. On a side we have one of the best storyline written in the last years of videogames, and the other side an atrocious hollow, boring and laughable gameplay mechanics.
If this was delivered more like a telltale game (the walking dead, wolf among us and so on) this would have been a spectacular 9/10.
But since this game is depicted as an rpg it fails BIG TIME.

The combat system it's absolutely b.u.l.l.s.h.i.t. You cannot prearrange any sort of tactic to take care of your companion I.A. so everytime you want to use a special ability you have to switch to your companion character and make him use the ability you want to.
The enemies are divided in 3 types: cloth armor, leather, mail and plate. Each of these are weak against a certain type of weapon (cutting, smashing, perforating) providing a 15% bonus damage when the proper weakness gets spoiled fighting the right enemy with the right type of weapon. All good right? Nope.
Because infact you can equip only  2 type of weapon at time. Ok, you can equip 4, but there's no point in doing it, because the 15% bonus wouldn't make up for the fact that you're not skilled enough to use that weapon, so you will end up missing more than hitting your opponent. So you'd end up picking two type of weapons to specialize in and stick to them, making them level up once every level (you will be able to rise the skills to a max of 100, for example you want to get good using two hands swords, you'd rise the swords skill under the cutting tree of the weapons)

If you manage to get through this (especially in the first few hours of the game, i'd say atleast six) you'll be rewarded with a fantastic storyline, and at times yes, it will make up making you almost forget all the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t this game brings to the table. Ah, and i wished (except done in some cases) they'd use much better voice actors, some of them are coming through seriously flat, which is a bugger since this game has such an elaborate and fine storyline to tell. Atleast some of the were good.

This could have been so much better if instead of trying to milk the games of throne cow" it would have been properly give its time to develop gameplay wise.
I'm hoping in the telltale game coming later in 2015. If that game will have on par storyline with this
date: i'd consider it as a The Walking Dead (season 1) contender. Fingers crossed."

reviewText:
This game is wonderful, and definitely gives that same feeling you get from watching the show.

I would recommend it because it is very true to the feel of Game of Thrones, however, there is one rather large issue that I hope the developers will fix eventually.

The only camera control is MANUAL. You have to constantly click the middle mouse button to center your view, or hold down the right mouse button while you run around, which disorients me quite fast. The camera is directly over your shoulder, so if you happen to turn around without using the mouse to orient your camera, you can only see your face and behind you.

Camera controls are so basic to any game, I'm shocked they don't at least have an option to set it to automatically follow you at least. If they fixed that one glaring issue, I'd whole-heartedly recommend this game. As it is, I am still enthralled enough I'm going to keep trying to play it and hope they add camera controls. I doubt I'll be able to play in large doses, though. Trying to pay attention to the camera on top of everything else gave me a migraine. =<

I'll preface this by saying that I really like the Game of Thrones series, so it's not about disliking the content or anything (what little of it I saw in this game). I bought the other game made by Telltale, and liked it well enough. And so, encouraged by the positive reviews I read, I thought maybe this one would be interesting.

I really, REALLY wanted to like this title, but sadly I couldn't play it long enough to draw conclusions about the game content itself; due to all the issues that started popping up. Of course I wish I could have played further into the game before posting a review, but no sale. It's terrible. My computer isn't exactly perfect but it isn't the worst either. I can play Skyrim and Bioshock Infinite on it without a problem. Yet somehow the cinematics on this game had characters that looked like floating sets of clothing with teeth, eyeballs, and discolored blotches like a toddler got loose with the crayons and doodled all over a world map. And whenever it wasn't bugging out, the graphics were shoddy at best, with a handful of textures that looked moderately adequate.

The battle system glitched out to high hell also. I was left sittin' there like a lemon, unable to move, with no status ailments that I was aware of, with full energy, then I noticed...I AM moving, but... at a pace that makes glaciers look like Turbo. Oh, joy.

Good thing I bought it on sale. I'm going to give it another try sometime for the sake of saying I gave it a fair shake, but I'm not holding my breath. What a let-down.

reviewText:
I had to go back and check what year this game was released, the graphics reminded me so much of vanilla World of Warcraft, but with more of an attempt at realism. The voice acting was pretty bad, particularly the main characters which is unfortunate because there is a lot of dialogue. The characters do this very odd shifting stance while they talk where they put one hand on their hip, it's very distracting to see these big burly characters with one hand on their hip while they talk to each other.

It took what felt like a long time to get to the first combat in the game, the combat uses an action queue system. It is not hack and slash at all, your combat actions are on a timer to complete, you have to manually select enemies to attack and switch between controlled characters during combat to queue up actions or let your allies auto attack. I found the combat to be the most disappointing, it just felt very boring to queue up attacks and sit back waiting for them to countdown.

I definitely made a mistake buying this game, I thought the graphics looked fine in the screenshots but I found them very outdated when I started playing. From the little research I did it looked so much like a hack and slash combat system and found that the queued combat system drained the last of my resolve to play through this game. Only made it to the third chapter I believe, just wanted to warn other people from making my mistakes. At least I got it on a sale.

reviewText:
Personal rating: 6/10

Budget: A fan of the ASOIAF universe should buy this, other RPG fans; only if on sale.
Lenght: A couple of days at least.

As an ASOIAF fan, I also didn't quite feel like the game was a necessary expansion into the universe. Let me put it this way: I don't regret getting it, but now that I've tried it, I realize I could have done without it.

reviewText:
Numerous reviews state that this game's story is good.
This very well may be true.
But to enjoy the story you'll have to deal with:
- Amateurish writing
- Mostly bad voice acting
- Clunky controls
- Bare bones empty world
- Dull combat
- Very little side activities

I couldn't.

If you're sure you can do all that and enjoy the supposedly good story or you're a huge GoT fan - buy it on a sale.
Otherwise it is likely to be disappointing in my opinion.

reviewText:
Sadly this game was released before FOCUS realized its combat system was garbage and was repelling 40% of the people who would otherwise buy their games. While a step up from Of Orcs and Men, it still falls very short of enjoyable.

If you aren't aware of the combat system, its a mix of strategy turn-based and hack-n-slash. You plug in attacks x,y,x and then your character does attacks x,y,x in sequence - not as you press it. This means youre basically standing still creating sequences of attacks before you even know what the oppenent is going to do - almost like rock, paper, scissors. (the slow reaction time / animations mean that you can't do it in real time, even if you wanted too).
It's disgusting and doesn't feel right to play. Doesn't feel like youre actually controlling the character, its strange.

If you can bear the clunky, semi-realtime combat - I'm sure this game would be great.

My god where do i start. This game is just awful. It just doesnt work in any way. The only reason i played it was because it had the Game of Thrones name on it. With the franchise attached to it i was quite biased in its favour before playing it but nothing could cover up the monstrosity that is this game

The combat doesn't seem to make any sense. It's not like one of those games where you know the combat has a learning curve that you'll eventually get used to. The combat in this game just doesnt make any sense and i can't see anyone getting comfortable with it. The camera as well is just horrible. It doesnt go where you want it to and just ends up disorientating the player. Story-wise i cant really comment on because i didn't play for very long. It could be a good story but everything else just completely dwarfs that possibilty

Pros:
-Its called Game of Thrones

Cons:
-The combat system doesn't work at all
-The camera mirrors the combat systems perfectly

Conclusion:
While i recognise that the cons list isn't long and some people might be able to see past a couple of faults these are just too big to overlook in my opinion. I cannot recommend this game to anyone. It tries too hard to incorporate to many aspects of other successful titles ( Dragon Age, KOTOR ) but just fails miserably. Don't waste your money

1/10 (1 is literally just because i love GoT)

reviewText:
TL;DR: This is hardly a game at all, allowing for very little combat choices and even less exploration.  The story is good, though, and ties into the franchise quite well.  Music is straight out of the show, and some memorable characters came from the show to appear in this game.  However, it is not fun; it is tedious.

Full review:

For starters, you choose dialogue options in a similar fashion to Mass Effect but rarely see an actual difference in the responses from the other characters.  This illusion of interactivity works against the game because I would most likely be more immersed in the story if I could turn off the captions and watch everything like a movie.

If you manage to ignore the gigantic captions at the bottom of the screen, the characters are bland and unexciting.  This is a problem I have with The Elder Scrolls games, too.  Characters are unappealing and uninteresting.  They rarely do anything other than move their lips and maybe wail their arms about them in random directions.  Most of the time, they don't even move their heads!  The lack of animation leads to some major cinematic flaws which make this a hard story to follow, but in general, lack of animation would be OK if the gameplay could make up for it.

The gameplay consists of mostly menus, going from one place to another, and watching characters move in slow motion.  The combat is as unexciting as can be, yet you may find it frustrating due to the lack of a good user interface design.  I chose the normal difficulty level and could not get past the first non-tutorial fight without choosing the damage sponge class.  Did I mention the class system?  Yes, there's a class system, a damn good one!  Unfortunately, it goes to waste due to the horrible way it was implemented in combat.  Basically, the combat consists of pressing space to go into slomo mode, choosing a couple actions for your character(s), and then proceeding to watch those actions unfold.  It may sound like a decent strategy system, but it doesn't work.  The first battle was so difficult I had to do it four times, switching classes on the fourth try, requiring me to sit through a bunch of boring loading screens due to skipped cinematics replaying everything all over again.  A retry button would have been nice there.  Hell, an auto-save would have been nice there!

The overall presentation of this game's story is a mixed bag of awesomeness and futility.  The entire game is voiced, but the characters aren't animated very well.  The combat system makes me want to avoid combat rather than look forward to it.  The menu is poorly implemented but has a nice visual appeal.  The control scheme is horrible both in the combat and in explorable areas, requiring you to use the numpad and the mouse at the same time for example just to do a simple task like change your target.  The music was straight out of the show, so it was awesome, but come on, we can just listen to the music elsewhere.

I do not recommend this game, because it is absurdly frustrating to play and offers little in the form of entertainment.  Fans of the show may find some redeemable value in the character appearances or the backstory of The Wall, but nothing justifies playing through the entirety of this game in my opinion.  My patience wears thin after just one hour.

reviewText:
I am a fan of RPGs and asoiaf and heartily recommend against playing this game.

This game looks 10 years old. The controls are non standard in a horrible way and consequently are aggravating to control. The mouse only moves the camera if you hold a button and it is far too sensitive, also 'w' does not move you forward but about 30 degrees off forward, your hand is expected to be on the number pad and on wasd during combat. It's poor to play but I wasn't expecting anything brilliant in that department, I wanted to dive into westeros.

You start (I only played the start) at the wall which was disappointing, later you play a red priest in the free cities but I could not stick with it for that long. Call me a fangirl but what I like about asoiaf was that it felt realistic given the rules it wrote for itself. The sworn brother you play can warg with his Bull Terrier (at the wall, this dog would freeze to death, as a ranger's companion he would die of exhaustion) but you are labelled as a skin changer rather than a warg despite never (so far as I can gather) going into other animals. But a warg? They're rare to the point of nonexistent south of the wall.
One of your first missions is to find a brother who ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and killed a new recruit (mole's town has a brothel; there are boys there to the best of my recollection, no reason to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• a recruit). The player character called the brothers crows (taking back the word, I imagine) and they talk about white walkers and others as different beings on multiple occasions.

After too many, you didn't read the books!" moments I gave up.

Avoid"

reviewText:
I can't understand the positive reviews for the game. Normally I don't recommend or criticize a game until I've played several hours at least, but in this case I had to make an exception. I've only played half an hour and I can honestly say this was one of the worst games I've ever touched.

As a huge Game of Thrones fan I thought that no matter how bad the game itself was, the story would be worth playing it for. Unfortunately, the story might be good, but it's delivered atrociously. The voice acting is TERRIBLE and I mean comically bad. Definiely exacerbated by the awkward pacing, and the dismal dialogue itself. I can't believe any game would allow dialogue of this poor quality. It feels like it was written by a bad fanfic writer who read the Wikipedia summary of an ASOIAF book a couple of years ago. I know George RR Martin can tend to be a bit flowery in his dialogue, but this game has you going Who the hell has ever talked like that ever" too many times.

After enduring the first few cutscenes I was already on the verge of quitting (seriously it felt like the writers were trying really really hard to remind us this was a Game of Thrones game
recommended: unnecessary references to lore). But when I actually tried the combat and gameplay I knew this game was unsalvagable trash. I felt like I've seen that same skills tree in a dozen other games

reviewText: Despite the TV show imo sucking balls and showing way too much limp ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, I enjoy this game. It's a fun game with decent production value. It has one of the smoothest game engines I've ever seen. Graphics aren't great and character models suck and animations could be much better but the medieval setting is captured nicely. Voice acting is done well, however a bit too monotone. The part that made me like this game was the combat. It is like combat in a mmo: there are no attack buttons to mash, just auto attack and use some skills. You press the left button on the gamepad and it brings up an ability wheel and you select actions and it puts them in a que, then you hit it again and you go back to combat and perform the abilities. I appreciate the combat so much because I'm an oldschool gamer at heart and love Final Fantasy games, so I've always liked selecting abilities in combat a bit more than just button mashing. There is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• of talking so either be ready to skip a lot of dialogue or read it, in which the storyline is actually pretty interesting imo.\nThumbs up good game, 7.5/10

reviewText:
No spoilers.

This game got a really bad reputation for seemingly very little reason.

Clearly this was a fairly small studio who have been thrown a license and tried to do a good job, and honestly they did. I think if they have more of a budget or more staff this could have been one of the all time great RPGs. The story is fantastic,  George R.R. Martin was definately involved in crafting this thing because it is also apparently canon, the houses and events are part of the actual story.

It starts 15 years after Robert Baratheons rebellion, the story is told through two different perspectives through two characters. You start of with Mors, a brother of The Nights Watch fighting wildlings north of the wall. Then in chapter two you're introduced to Alestar, an exiled knight who deserted his family and lands to get away from his deeds during Roberts rebellion. Alestar fled to Bravos where he discovered the Lord of Light and became a Red Priest he returns to his home after 15 years for the burial of his father.

I can't really say too much about the story because it's Game of Thrones (and believe me this is Game of Thrones), and I'm resisting the urge to quote Ramsay Bolton as it is so moving on.

In terms of the game itself, it's serviceable for the purposes of delivering the story.

To me it felt a lot like Dragon Age 2, but with more corners cut and I know people are probably freaked out by that notion so allow me to clarify. You will see multiple character models which are exactly the same, most of the time you won't notice but occasionally they'll be standing right next to each other. The combat is fairly lack lustre it's your basic select skills and wait" simulator. Locations are quite small and not very impressive you do feel as though Westeros is a stage rather than a living breathing world dark and full of terrors.

However all of this only prevents the game from being great rather than what it is

reviewText:
A very casual RPG.

It definitely doesn't comply with current standards when it comes to graphics and gameplay; despite being just a couple of years old it kind of feels like it was made a decade ago. But the story is very engaging, and it compels you to keep playing just to know how it unfolds. Much like the books (or TV series), not everything turns out the way you think. And the ending is so epic. The game is a bit slow at first but it gets better as you progress; and it's long enough for a casual RPG.

It's not a bad attempt to translate the franchise to video game format. It's definitely worth a try.

If you're a fan of the franchise, or if you're really into RPGs, you must play this game. Otherwise I recommend you to only buy it when it's on a sale.

reviewText: Most underrated game of the year? This is nowhere as bad as the reviews claimed. In fact, it's pretty good. It does have faults: very linear, mediocre level design, and very few NPCs make the game world kind of boring. However, the combat is pretty good (especially if you play on hard) and the character builds are different enough from eachother to make more than one playthrough worth while. But the real reason to play this is the storyline. I'm a big fan of the books and I was actually kind of impressed how the writers for this managed to replicate pretty accurately everything that is great about the books, without seeming like they are merely rehashing pre-existing storylines. It even had a couple twists that genuinely surprised me, which was nice.\n\nThere might be better RPGs out there in terms of gameplay, but if you like the GOT universe or just like games that put story before all else (even, sometimes, at the cost of gameplay) then this is well worth a playthrough.

reviewText:
For a game based on a TV show*, it's pretty good. While I normally prefer turn-based combat, the real-time-with-pause works pretty well. You have to balance inflicting status effects (on fire, stunned, knocked down, etc.) with matching extra powered attacks while always saving a bit of power to throw in an interrupt. You're often controlling 2 characters (and sometimes also a dog), so there is a lot of room for strategy. Like most real-time-with-pause systems though, the fights always devolve into a big pile of guys bouncing all over the place.

The story is really about as good as it gets for something like this. It all takes place before the show starts and focuses on new characters who often run into characters from the show. The writing is ok, and the story is interesting. Some of the side quests are fun.

There are a lot of negatives though. Some of the quest are really wonky - you have to basically try every dialogue option. It seemed like a crap-shoot to figure out the best dialogue option. The results were just too random.

The visuals are all over the place. The main two character's faces look great, but some of the cast members are almost unrecognizable. The texture quality is often pretty bad. For example, the doors look like something from a 10-year-old game: just a flat texture on a very thin bit of polygons. Like, the handles are never modeled making them look really out of place. Tree, flowers, etc. often look terrible. Oh, it's also worth mentioning that the game is over-the-shoulder third-person, so it can be a real pain to look around. As far as I could tell there was no first-person look" option. The FOV was really low

reviewText:
Its a great roleplaying game, plain and simple.  If you are a fan of the Game of Thrones series like I am, and like roleplaying games, its just plain neat.

I really am enjoying being in the nights watch and seeing the ominous, thrilling wall that goes on forever.

The combat is tactical not action.  The game does say that in the description, but I thought it would be somewhat twitch based, it is not.  You choose the actions of the character and they carry them out in real time, but you can pause any time and change and/or que up orders.

Its a role playing game, which means you do get to build up your character, choose attributes and skills, buy, find, and equip different weapons and armor.  I love it.  Exploration pays off in finding new items, etc.

The graphics are fantastic at the highest settings and at 1600 by 900 resolution.  I know that people criticized the graphics for the Xbox, but the computer version to me at least, captures the world perfectly.

The dialogue and story is game of thrones, that simple.  Horrible actions, rough words, and intigue everywhere.  Do not let your children play this game.  The first quest is caused by some horrible, R rated actions.

A few things could be better.

You have to almost be on top of an item before you see it.  For example, you may see a bunch of crates across the room, but you have to walk over there and almost be touching them before you get an icon that there is something to grab.

The game appears to be fairly linear.  I'm very early in the game, but its not a wide open world to explore, its more of a tight knit story to follow.  There are sidequests, and several neat choices in the dialogue, but this is a more linear game.

Needs more actors from the series.  The only voices that I believe are in it from the series are Varas and the commander of the Night's watch, thats it.  Since this takes place parallel to season 1, there are so many others we could have met.  I don't know what other characters may be around, but even if we get to meet them, they won't be the same voices.

Anyways, I don't what was up with the Xbox version, but the pc special edition version is a great game if you would like to enjoy Westeros for a little bit while waiting for season 5.  Right now its on sale for 5 bucks.  Its a steal!

reviewText:
Game of Thrones title is fully earned here - evil will triumph and the innocent blood will grease the gears of political schemes.

Writing is the main course here - the plot takes place shortly after Robert Baratheon's death, when the king's bast... errm... illegitimate children are being hunted. We have two main characters with separate storylines and motives, but they will be forced to take part in the political events. The atmosphere is very bleak, treachery lurks everywhere. The game features some of the most disturbing scenes in gaming - done so well, that the worst one isn't even graphic.

There are a lot of smaller and bigger choices to make, the consequences are often non-direct or delayed - but they have impact on the plot.

The game is off-putting at the beginning - the visuals are outdated (though some of the textures, armors etc. look weirdly good) and the combat feels slow and boring. But if only you'll stay a bit longer, hopefully you'll find yourself in the story's grip. The graphics will still be awful, but servicable. Combat will pick up a bit though once you'll learn more skills and get more stamina to use them - it will still be a bit boring as it's very tactical and focues on disabling and exploiting enemies (at higher difficulty levels it's very challenging).

Get the Beyond of Wall DLC if you decide to play the game - it's a short prequel and it's great.

reviewText:
Its a great roleplaying game, plain and simple.  If you are a fan of the Game of Thrones series like I am, and like roleplaying games, its just plain neat.

I really am enjoying being in the nights watch and seeing the ominous, thrilling wall that goes on forever.

The combat is tactical not action.  The game does say that in the description, but I thought it would be somewhat twitch based, it is not.  You choose the actions of the character and they carry them out in real time, but you can pause any time and change and/or que up orders.

Its a role playing game, which means you do get to build up your character, choose attributes and skills, buy, find, and equip different weapons and armor.  I love it.  Exploration pays off in finding new items, etc.

The graphics are fantastic at the highest settings and at 1600 by 900 resolution.  I know that people criticized the graphics for the Xbox, but the computer version to me at least, captures the world perfectly.

The dialogue and story is game of thrones, that simple.  Horrible actions, rough words, and intigue everywhere.  Do not let your children play this game.  The first quest is caused by some horrible, R rated actions.

A few things could be better.

You have to almost be on top of an item before you see it.  For example, you may see a bunch of crates across the room, but you have to walk over there and almost be touching them before you get an icon that there is something to grab.

The game appears to be fairly linear.  I'm very early in the game, but its not a wide open world to explore, its more of a tight knit story to follow.  There are sidequests, and several neat choices in the dialogue, but this is a more linear game.

Needs more actors from the series.  The only voices that I believe are in it from the series are Varas and the commander of the Night's watch, thats it.  Since this takes place parallel to season 1, there are so many others we could have met.  I don't know what other characters may be around, but even if we get to meet them, they won't be the same voices.

Anyways, I don't what was up with the Xbox version, but the pc special edition version is a great game if you would like to enjoy Westeros for a little bit while waiting for season 5.  Right now its on sale for 5 bucks.  Its a steal!

reviewText:
Game of Thrones title is fully earned here - evil will triumph and the innocent blood will grease the gears of political schemes.

Writing is the main course here - the plot takes place shortly after Robert Baratheon's death, when the king's bast... errm... illegitimate children are being hunted. We have two main characters with separate storylines and motives, but they will be forced to take part in the political events. The atmosphere is very bleak, treachery lurks everywhere. The game features some of the most disturbing scenes in gaming - done so well, that the worst one isn't even graphic.

There are a lot of smaller and bigger choices to make, the consequences are often non-direct or delayed - but they have impact on the plot.

The game is off-putting at the beginning - the visuals are outdated (though some of the textures, armors etc. look weirdly good) and the combat feels slow and boring. But if only you'll stay a bit longer, hopefully you'll find yourself in the story's grip. The graphics will still be awful, but servicable. Combat will pick up a bit though once you'll learn more skills and get more stamina to use them - it will still be a bit boring as it's very tactical and focues on disabling and exploiting enemies (at higher difficulty levels it's very challenging).

Get the Beyond of Wall DLC if you decide to play the game - it's a short prequel and it's great.

A fantastic story driven game that will leave any fan of the Song of Fire and Ice series happy. This a purely story driven game that has the dark tone and twists that make the books and the TV series great. I will admit that the first few hours of the game is slow and it may straw people away from this game, but don't this game picks up the pace and never lets go. This game requires patentince and there are scenes that last for a very long time but are filled with great dialogue and even better characters.

Many people complain that there hasn't been a great game that the series of Fire and Ice deserves, I would disagree with them. This game is a great compaianon piece to the world and lore of this sereies of the books and TV shows. This has a great and lengthy main story that will keep you on the edge of your seat. It was very hard for me to put down the controller once i started it. At over 20 hours it provide a lot of great sotry moments. Also the side quest do not detract from the story at all and adds an incredible amount depth to the story and the characters. If you do all the side quests it will add about another 10 hours to the game, I would recommand that you do so.

The gameplay of this game is a little weak and has a very steep learning curve. I'm not the biggest stragiests, so when I found out that the combet requires to you really think, it took me a little bit to get used to. But once I put the effort into it it become very rewarding.

The graphics are not that great but they make up for it in the art department and the ability to recreate areas fome the show and books. the atmoshere is thick with style and can bery nice to look at. The game play and the graphics are not what makes this game great though, that's due to story. Get this game for the story, you will be a happy camper if you do so.

If you're someone that does not care for stories in games and only worries about gameplay, I would reccomand that you don't pick up this game. But if you are someone that love an incredible, darkcharacter rich and lore heavy story then this is the game for you.

Pros
-An amazing story that stays true(for the most part) to its source materail
-Two wonderfull main characters that are great to play and level up
-Two intersting intersecting stories that clash in a really great momnet
-Fantastic vioce work from the main characters of the game
-A Lengthy story that will keep you at the edge of your seat

Cons

-First few hours are slow
-Console port with no grahpic options escept for resolution (that can be changed by going into the invidia control panel and fixing that yourself)

9/10

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings on this game. Story-wise, it remains loyal to the series and introduces new characters as well as characters from the show (with some of the actual cast providing voices!)
Basically, the game is set in a similar style to the books. You play as two characters, Mors, a ranger of the Night's Watch, and Alester, a red priest who has returned from Braavos to reclaim his father's seat as Lord. You switch between both characters  every chapter. The RPG elements are great, allowing you to choose your style of play. Mors and Alester have different fighting styles, and you can pick which path you want them to go down. You can upgrade your skill tree, add points to weapons etc... all the typical RPG things. What ultimately kills it however is the combat system.  When you engage in battle you select an enemy and you can line up attacks. Using such an old combat model for this type of game is its downfall. I could look past some of the other aspects except this.

Performance-wise, the game is stable and runs smoothly. The graphics are dated, but they're not bad so to say. Just don't expect super beautiful graphics. The enviroments are also a bit shallow. Riverspring, during the riots felt a bit bland to my taste. There was none of that true hateful spirit! You need to play the game to see for yourself. Apart from that the game hasn't aged well. It feels like it was made back in 2000.

But what about the story? The thing that made me a big fan of GoT is the story, which in this case this game has remained loyal to. The game takes place before the events of the first book, in a simpler time when Robert Baratheon was still whoring away, Eddard Stark's head was still on his shoulders and the realm was finally in peace after the downfall of the Targaryens. Some of the cast members from the show lent their voices! I was absolutely surprised when I heard Varys' spidery voice narrating the intro and good ol' Jeor Mormont giving orders to the Night's Watch. It's those little things that make this game so special.

It has it's flaws but if you are willing to overlook the outdated game mechanics, I recommend this. It's a must-get for any true GoT fan (It's better for readers of the book, but show-watchers are welcome to try it!) If you want a proper quality GoT experience, play Telltale's Game of Thrones game. There is far more polish and TV-esque story than this.

EDIT: Oh and I forgot to mention the voice acting. Apart from the cast who lent their voices (which sound just like in the show!) some of the voices can sound uninspired, like when they're saying, OH MY GOD WE'RE GONNA DIE!" They sound sort of bored. Not all the voices are like that

reviewText: Before I begin this review, understand that I was not a fan of Game of Thrones/ A Song of Ice and Fire and knew nothing about the series other than it had a bunch of main characters die all the time.  Playing it for the first time, I enjoyed how the two main characters were not really good characters but more so severely flawed characters put in desperate situations.  If you are wanting to play a game that had  similar characters to The Witcher, you may also enjoy the characters in this game.  Like most western rpgs,  the branching dialoge choices is a nice touch that adds  replay value and helps you get immersed in the setting of the game.  The gameplay is a cross between Dragon's Age Origin's queuing system as far as stacking different types of attacks/selecting party members and Witcher 2's slow down when you are trying to select attacks.  It works for the most part however I did have trouble in certain segments of the game.\nThe game has a very decent art style with really nice moon effects in the forest.  However character detail is very lacking and ugly.  The soundtrack was pretty decent, nothing that stood out and made it memorable but it was not bad either, just a bit repetitive.  The voice acting is definitly low budget however, some of the characters really put forth some awful lines of dialogue and made some scenes hiliarious when they were not supposed to be.   In addition, like most western rpgs, there are plenty of bugs and glitches that at one time forced me to load a previous save, 30 minutes back, so be warned to save often and have different save files just in case.\nFor the current asking price, it is in my opinion too much, wait till it gets on sale for under $10 and you should fine plenty of enjoyment with the game.  I would avoid the dlc however, the dog skin is just a skin pack and adds nothing to the gameplay or story.  The weapons pack is also not very well designed as you still have to pay  a merchant to get the weapons that are extremely expensive, you will eventually in the course of the game, get weapons that rival those dlc weapons. The one story dlc Beyond the Wall" is okay but very brief
date: do not get the dlc at the current asking price.\nWhile the game has many flaws

reviewText:
Game of Thrones is really an overlooked and underrated game on the field of RPGs. It tells a great story of 2 knights in the world of George R.R. Martin's Game of Thrones and fits well with the Book/TV Show. The game's strength is storytelling, and this is probably the problem for some percent of players, because there is a lot of conversation and narration in the game. Most of the game you will be running around and talking to people solving the next puzzle of the story (i would say around 70/30% for Conversations/Fight). The Fighting system is good (reminds me of Dragon Age) and there is a decent amount of skills, loot and customization to play with. The game is fairly linear but there are some secondary/optional quests to do as well as some minor exploration. The graphics is outdated but it works for me as it gives a good overall feel for the game.

As said the storytelling and the voice acting what makes this game great and worth checking. It will not spoil the show/book just minor part, but i would recommend watching Season One at least to understand some parts and easter eggs".

Game of Thrones may not be the best RPG on the world but it‚Äôs definitely a worthy one. It requires patience and I would mostly recommend for players who prefer the story instead of the action. Try It out and May the Seven watch over you!

7/10"

reviewText:
Now, this is a hard game to talk about,
Personally, I like the story, the idea is good, there were twists in it I didn't expect and it's just about good enough that I think it can fit into this world well
It has however got it's flaws, such as magic working before the return of the dragons, that doesn't fit at all with the time of the story at which the game is based. Most of these isues however I will overlook

The more pressing issues are the gameplay and the graphics in this game. I would rather have a game where I could play one of the main characters 1st person and do the fighting myself instead of using this 3rd person mechanic the game has
The game generally feels unfinished. It's all of the small things, such as being able to walk through some walls, ai not working, seemingly unbeatable foes at parts of the game, badly scaled difficulty and the mish-mash of high-res textures on armour and super low-res on weaponry.
It just looks and feels poor

All in all, the story is good, well thought through and a decent length of 18 hours supprisingly, however the poorly designed gameplay and lack of attention to the graphics and AI in the game do ruin the feel of the playthrough.

reviewText:
The game's good. Really good.

First of all, i must say i'm not really a GoT fan. I didn't enjoy the tv series that much in particular. I didn't read the books either. I really don't know if the game is befitting to the original content or not. And i simply don't care too.

It's fan-frigin-tastic as an RPG game. Playing not just one but two different main characters is fenomenal. This is unique. Almost feels like two different main stories but with a colliding fate. Very very satisfying to see diverse dialogues between them based on your actions and development in the game. Most dialogue options are very diverse and has impact on bigger things. In the end, you will be testing your wits against the game. There are several different ending possibilities but non of them are really definitive good or bad choices. Grim, just as expected from Martin :) The Voice acting is also astonishing and the music just feels right.

Combat is OK. Might feel clunky at first. Very basic but it's not spoon feed either. You have to use your skills very very carrefully and calculate the outcome. You will be forced to run and get creative with your skill combos. Very demanding and challanging especially in higher difficulty settings. In most situations you have to nuke the enemies before they can act. Otherwise you'll get hurt big time. Enemy AI isn't really perfect but they are not mindless zombies either. As you level up, you may think yourself on a easy spot but the game still suprises you with different sittuations. Your characters has different set of skill trees that compliment each other. However, some skills are slightly unbalanced. Also i hould mention, there's a limited slow time feature which you have to use in order to queue your skills. You can not pause the game in mid combat and manage your characters.

And then there's Westeros. Quite nicely designed. it's not an open world map but the fast travel option gives you the illusion that it is. I find that the level designs are quite linear however theres always a couple of different ways to deal wƒ±th the challanges ahead. You find different equipment and treasures as you explore the every corner (tho %95 of the loot is just plain crap). What's really annoying is to run across the maps again and again to complete side quests. Previously killed enemies doesn't spawn so you don't get any exp or loot either. Pretty much all the side quests has to be completed in order to get more exp. to deal with harder sittuations. Pretty boring after a while and kills the replayable value.

Graphics are not the best but who cares. More than OK in my book. Detailed equipments are nice. Nothing out of place. Animations are quite nice but walking animations may feel clunky and slow paced at first. Slowing time in combat looks just great.

It's clear that the game takes after titles such as dragon age and witcher. It has strong points and weak points. I definitely recommend this title to anyone who likes medival RPG games in general.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings on this game. Story-wise, it remains loyal to the series and introduces new characters as well as characters from the show (with some of the actual cast providing voices!)
Basically, the game is set in a similar style to the books. You play as two characters, Mors, a ranger of the Night's Watch, and Alester, a red priest who has returned from Braavos to reclaim his father's seat as Lord. You switch between both characters  every chapter. The RPG elements are great, allowing you to choose your style of play. Mors and Alester have different fighting styles, and you can pick which path you want them to go down. You can upgrade your skill tree, add points to weapons etc... all the typical RPG things. What ultimately kills it however is the combat system.  When you engage in battle you select an enemy and you can line up attacks. Using such an old combat model for this type of game is its downfall. I could look past some of the other aspects except this.

Performance-wise, the game is stable and runs smoothly. The graphics are dated, but they're not bad so to say. Just don't expect super beautiful graphics. The enviroments are also a bit shallow. Riverspring, during the riots felt a bit bland to my taste. There was none of that true hateful spirit! You need to play the game to see for yourself. Apart from that the game hasn't aged well. It feels like it was made back in 2000.

But what about the story? The thing that made me a big fan of GoT is the story, which in this case this game has remained loyal to. The game takes place before the events of the first book, in a simpler time when Robert Baratheon was still whoring away, Eddard Stark's head was still on his shoulders and the realm was finally in peace after the downfall of the Targaryens. Some of the cast members from the show lent their voices! I was absolutely surprised when I heard Varys' spidery voice narrating the intro and good ol' Jeor Mormont giving orders to the Night's Watch. It's those little things that make this game so special.

It has it's flaws but if you are willing to overlook the outdated game mechanics, I recommend this. It's a must-get for any true GoT fan (It's better for readers of the book, but show-watchers are welcome to try it!) If you want a proper quality GoT experience, play Telltale's Game of Thrones game. There is far more polish and TV-esque story than this.

EDIT: Oh and I forgot to mention the voice acting. Apart from the cast who lent their voices (which sound just like in the show!) some of the voices can sound uninspired, like when they're saying, OH MY GOD WE'RE GONNA DIE!" They sound sort of bored. Not all the voices are like that

(if youre a got fan, dont read further the () part unless you like to be upset. i wanted to vent about this for a long time, now ill do it.
first, you cannot ignore the fact that its a game of thrones game. that means that its basically a 'unconsented sexual intercourse'/woman-child-murder/incest porn in a mediocre, generic fantasy setting - with good writing. i watched the first episode of the tv show - that was more than enough - and as i remember it starts with incest and ends with a child murder; in the first two acts of the game theres a 'unconsented sexual intercourse' of a young man and a very young girl, but headless corpses and old women are also a fair play in the minds of the writers. im horrified at the success of the franchise, its one thing to write something like this, money is money but im amazed how many sick people are around to enjoy it. and this time there is no excuse like in the case of spartacus eg, 'we wanted to make it realistic, this is how it was', people, its a fantasy! yep, a 'unconsented sexual intercourse'/murder/incest fantasy. seek professional help. im aware that now i have angered about half the population of planet earth but i dont care much as i dont have a high opinion of the human race anyway. i have a small excuse for playing the game, it was a part of a bundle, got decent reviews, so here we are.)

i was a part worried, having played of orks and men recently and, well, i didnt like it much. however many problems with that (somewhat later!) game were not present in got.
-the attribute/ability/skill/trait system was much more refined and i felt actually compelled to think ahead and plan for my two characters.
-in got you have much more freedom (something i very much appreciate in an rpg), you can travel back and forth, find new quests or secrets you missed.
-it is more pleasing to the eye.
-voice acting was great in both games, with a few miscasts (for minor characters) i guess they had to ask the janitor to fill in,
-path finding is much better in got, there was only a few times when the not-player-controlled-character stuck somewhere (although there was a fun moment when the dog was stuck on a stairs under mors, both becoming unmovable).
-i played alaster as assassin, there wasnt much assassiny about him: couldnt sneak, and poisoned blades should be maybe used in more covert fashion. at least we had the hound...
-as with of orks and men music wasnt very memorable but fit right in, nothing to complain about (uh, i guess maybe it was from the tv show soundtrack and it might be an anthem or something for got fans, sorry about that.)
-sounds are funny when you approach a group of people talking, it starts and ends abruptly getting close or putting some distance between you and them. no worries, there are subtitles (which behave similarly btw) and they are on a repeat mode. you can listen in to every discussion you want.
-here, developers decided to make better equipment available to you as you progress in the game, not to throw the best stuff at you in the beginning. how traditional, how dull (sarcasm, see ooam.)
-the game behaved reasonably well while alttabbing, not rock solid, there were a few crashes but nothing too frustrating. however i always had to mute the game as it doesnt turn off the sound when its in the background. minor inconvenience.
-and again, talk, talk, talk. and again, i like a good story, when the game isnt only about shooting, butchering (heh), blowing things up, but sometimes the game felt like a - somewhat - interactive novel. maybe i had problems only with the distribution of the fighting and talking scenes, im not sure, but in hindsight there were times when you talked for half an hour then ran around with the dog for half an hour then fouught for half an hour (half an hour=might have been much more).
-at least you can skip dialogue lines and cut scenes. not recommended btw only if you screwed up something and have to reload, but still, - though a feature which is common in the past 10 years - big step ahead from ooam.
-lenghtier than ooam, steam says i played 40 hours but considering my abuse of alttabbing its probably between 30-35.
-this also had some frustrating points, like the mark on your map showing an exit to your quest often led to a closed portal,
-or you could reforge that damned valyrian (or something) sword to anything - except for what i wanted, a two-handed mace,
-or the clunkiness of the character/inventory screens,
-or a lot of (small) things i cannot remember and cant check as i - celebrating having the game finished - deleted it immediatelly.

i enumerated faults and only improvements to my not-so-good experience with ooam but do not fret: this is a worthy game. far, faaar from being among the best, but a solid experience, entertaining, well written and most of the time quite well designed.
if you like the subgenre i think the deciding factor might be, where do you stand with game of thrones, the franchise. if you like it, im sure you will enjoy it quite much.
if your stomach tends to turn on describing or even depicting of incest and the most hideous kinds of 'unconsented sexual intercourses' and most vicious murders - well this might not be for you.
i enjoyed the story and the solid gameplay but im sure ill never want to do anything with got again. telltale got? im sorry, so long, and thanks for all the fishies!
still, ill wave the 'recommended' flag, as this game is a good effort, a worthy game, and im sure that many people with stronger stomachs (god, seems theres a lot of them!) would enjoy.

EDIT: 'unconsented sexual intercourse': you know what. quite hypocritical from valve, filtering the r word while selling a game which is full of it. urinates me off a bit.

reviewText:
Yeah, I'll recommend this game any day, to anyone.

First of all, you are bound to think the game is absolute ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• when you take your first few looks into it. If you wish to embark in this marvelous journey, prepare yourself to almost regret your purchase. Almost. First few chapters are boring, gameplay brings nothing new to the table, it's just a copy paste of RPGs like Dragon Age: Origins. There are few things to do and even fewer places to explore besides whats presented to you in the main quest line. The story of the game deals with small matters compared to what the books are all about and, although you will meet with famous characters and visit famous locations, you'll leave no permanent mark on the events that set out the war of the five kings.

But that's exactly the point of the story on this game, however. You don't matter, your little affairs don't matter and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you for thinking otherwise. The narrative on this thing is so cold and real it will make you think Martin wrote it himself. There are plot twists galore, plenty of dear characters dying and the bitter reality hitting like a brick every now and then. You'll be playing as Mors, a man of the Night's Watch, and Alester, a heir to lands in Westeros who became a Red Priest while in exile, only to return and witness the damage his absence caused to the lands he was supposed to rule. You'll grow to like these characters for what they are and, likewise, you'll grow to like the game's story. Hopefully, you'll put up with the game's bland mechanics and even have some fun with it once you understand that nothing in this game's game play is objectively bad, its just not revolutionary.

Yes, get this game. It'll start out a 2/10, but it will become a 8/10 by the time you're done with it, believe me.

Gameplay - 5/10
Soundtrack - 8/10
Graphics - 7/10
Content - 3/10
Challenge Level - 4/10
Replayability - 0/10

reviewText: Most underrated game of the year? This is nowhere as bad as the reviews claimed. In fact, it's pretty good. It does have faults: very linear, mediocre level design, and very few NPCs make the game world kind of boring. However, the combat is pretty good (especially if you play on hard) and the character builds are different enough from eachother to make more than one playthrough worth while. But the real reason to play this is the storyline. I'm a big fan of the books and I was actually kind of impressed how the writers for this managed to replicate pretty accurately everything that is great about the books, without seeming like they are merely rehashing pre-existing storylines. It even had a couple twists that genuinely surprised me, which was nice.\n\nThere might be better RPGs out there in terms of gameplay, but if you like the GOT universe or just like games that put story before all else (even, sometimes, at the cost of gameplay) then this is well worth a playthrough.

reviewText:
SPOILER FREE REVIEW
The Game of Thrones RPG isn't the perfect game, but it does have a perfect story. George R.R Martin helped write it and you can tell, especially with all the intrigue and twists and turns. The game suffers from annoying combat mechanics and there isn't that much to do besides the main quest and one or two side quests, but it is a perfect game for any hardcore ASOIAF fans.

The story is great and you play as two main characters, and you visit many places throughout the game. The iconic locations are in such as Castle Black and King's Landing, you can go to Mole's Town as well. But most of the NPC in the game just stand around and offer nothing to the story but to make the locations look full of life. You can also hear the authentic voices of Joer Mormont and Varys, and the voice acting of the two main characters is great also.

The combat is a good system, but the annoyance is being ganged on upon by 5-6 enemies at a time. Even on the easiest difficulty the combat was annoying, not hard, just a pain. Many times I just wanted to skip the combat and advance throughout the story. Levelling up is cool, and there are alot of cool items in the game. My character for example was weilding Ser Duncan's sheid, and you can even use The Red Viper's spear. Those items are included with the Weapon Pack DLC though.

Each Chapter" in the game has the main quest and 1-2 side quests you can do. Side quests usually help you out later with the main quest if you accomplish them. But once you complete the quests there is nothing to do in the game but maybe fight in the arenas to get more cash. Making cash is easy
date: just sell all the stuff you don't have. No need to really fight for it.\n\nThe game is great for all ASOIAF and GOT fans to enjoy. The story is great and you will feel for the characters
recommended: but just remember in GOT their is no such thing as a happy ending."

reviewText: This is an amazing game I found on sale on steam.  I've played many other RPGs before but this is one where you really had to think hard about every decision and their long term consequences.  You don't get to create your own characters but you really get immersed in the ones they present to you with their complicated back stories.  Neither are 'bad' or 'weak' character types and there is still a lot of freedom to choose your class and develop them how you want.  It's the true art of role playing to act and think like someone from a differnt time.  You realize how difficult survival and finding allies can be very quickly in this story when everyone has their own motivations that don't mirror your own.  There are multiple endings which leave some things left unanswered but I enjoyed that since it gives room for the imagination to determine how you would react to the situation based on how you played your characters.

reviewText:
As others have stated this is definitely a story driven game. On the story alone I would recommend GOT.

At first I was not impressed with the combat but as the game progressed and the 2 heroes united I felt the game take on a different tone. More abilities became available and maybe sticking with the same 2 characters I learned how to use them effectively and had a more enjoyable time. Combat became more frequent which may also had something to do with my enjoyment.

I am still not a complete fan of the combat system however it is used in several of the DEVs games. As is the same awful camera controls. Once I got over the fact I would experience at times not being able to see my characters fully while in combat and during some cut scenes having my character stuck in a door or looking through my companions head or at a wall(etc...) I didn't hate it as much.

When I play I think of replayability. At first I thought NO. however during my game I rethought that and even though I would not immerse myself in the dialogue as I did It still may be fun trying the different combat stances and actually striving to finish all the side quests. I also think of bang for the buck(joy for the price) and since I bought GOT at a huge discount I definitely got my moneys worth for 1 play and if I do come back in a month or more than the bang will only increase.

The strongest point of the game is the story, although I didn't watch a single episode of GoT I found myself really into the characters and their world, I also find myself being attached to some characters just to suddently see them die :(. The gameplay is quite simple compared to other RPGs, which may satisfy more action-oriented players like me, do not expect the character developing to be complex, it's pretty straight-forward. on the technical size the game those well in general.

Now to the cons: first, the camera angel is frustrating, you'll often find yourself confused about what's going on, especially in tight places; the some of the game mechanics are not explained so  well by the tutorials, so you'll maybe a bit confused sometimes; animations and cutscenes are quite poor and far from interesting; the choises you make through the game don't affect the ending so much.

Overall it's a very simple RPG with a very good story and decent gameplay. 7.5

If you like the stories of Westeros, then I would say that this is worth buying when on sale. The story in itself is very good, though the game is no where near as polished as it should be.

The combat can be clunky as whilst it isnt turn based (You assign skills in a slowed down real time), it can be very repetitive and there are often clipping issues where the characters will either occupy the same space or vibrate" when they are standing half inside a wall. The system itself though is pretty easy to master once you understand the roles of each character (I always use Mors as a Landed knight and so he "tanks" whilst Alester can damage the enemy)

The quest system can be frustrating too if you are new to RPG's as if you miss a slight detail
date: you will pretty much fail the side quests. Most of the side quests can be completed over several chapters
recommended: but if you miss a specific pickup that starts the quest in the chapter where it has become available then you won't be able to complete the quest once you have moved on in the story. This can be awkward for achievment hunters.\n\nI do wonder how this story would have turned out if it had been developed by a bigger studio

reviewText:
I immedietly noticed this game used the actual soundtrack from the series and has some actors from the series actually voice act their characters in the game. That's a big plus.

It's unfortunate that the rest of the game makes it seem as if the entire budged was thrown at exactly that, and everything else was rushed or just left alone.
There's constant flickering in some textures. When starting combat there's a very colorful, mosaic-like plane on the sword for a second. A lot of the animations are rather unnaturally looking. Example of this is heads turning far further back than humanly possible. Walking pases are off, the lip-sync looks like people didn't even try to sync it.. Being someone familiar with 3D modelling and animation I can tell you that this is rather poorly done. The textures are low resolution, too.

The dialogue is rather cringe-worthy at times and there are a lot of aspects that make this game not hold true to the actual environment of the universe. One immediate example is the Night's Watch. In this game they have good armour, a lot of food, halls are lit and seem warm. Whereas we know that the Night's Watch isn't being looked after in the books and the show. They need men, they need supplies; they don't have good armour.

The dialogue, as mentioned before, is pretty cringy. Something that seemed odd to me was (close to the beginning) that I, as Mors, got to carry out the death sentence of the first guy I track. That's a commander's duty, not mine. I'm some ranger, a good one yes, but I am still just a ranger. Some of the dialogue options you get are really bad and don't keep you immersed at all. Everything just seemed very forced.

The combat is rather lackluster. This kind of combat is good (like in Dragon Age) but it has to be done well.

All of this combined made it very hard to enjoy any of the story.

I know this isn't a great review at this point, I'll probably edit and fill it out later. But as of now I'd say don't get this game unless you get it in some bundle. I'm sure there are some people who could find enjoyment in this, but then again there are people who enjoy Goat Simulator P:
Jokes aside, I don't mean to bash this game; 3D animation and modelling is hard not to mention putting all of that together into a working game.

Basically; some may like this and some may not. It depends on you, but I wouldn't recommend it. If you're really that GoT-starved that you need anything you can get, go for it.

NOTE: my playtime is rather low, keep in mind I played this game offline, too.

reviewText: This game is nothing more than a few simple mechanics allowing you to walk (assuming you can find your way) between a seemingly endless series of cutscenes. Story is... ok.. just a snippet of some of the most boring portions of the books that vaguely attempts to tie itself in with the TV series. The Water Dancer mechanics don't really work, archers are useless. When not watching cut scenes or holding absurdly long conversations the game is little more than a treasure hunt with some random mindless killing. There is one puzzle, but it is so simple a child could solve it in seconds. The options for Mors have very little bearing on the story at all, not mych better for Alester - though at least some choice there. But bugs, wow so many little areas with glitches in them. I would not recommend that anyone buys this game at all, not for more than a few dollars anyway.
